reviewText: This is where KISS started to stink up the joint. I regret buying this DVD at this point. Much of it is unwatchable to me. Yes I will admit that I am and Ace and Peter kinda guy. I like the original line up. That being said I have no problem with the men that replaced them. Eric Carr was a great man that had a tragic end. And some of the post-makeup music was decent.The problem here is KISS started to get slopy, old and lame. Heck, even Paul and Gene ADMIT it in to comentary. They use phraises like "our costumes looked like we belong in Disney World", "we had lost our edge" and "we were more about making money that being KISS". They also admit that the crowds that loved them so much were gone. 12,000 seat arenas had 2,000 people in them. Paul remebers throwing a pick and having it hit bare ground on the floor. No one was around to pick it up!As you can tell, if you want to get depressed about what KISS had become this is your DVD!!!Plus these concerts dont sound very good. Paul is singing off key, same with Gene. The songs, even the really old ones, sound off. Its just WRONG how KISS was back then. They were a shell of what KISS was in the 70's.Also, the material that is included on these DVD's is incomplete. The interviews are edited. Mainly because Gene Simmons wanted to take out the parts of the Tom Schneider interview he didnt like. Some of the concerts also appear to have been shortened. I dont ever remeber seeing KISS play only 5 songs in a set. But a couple of the performaces are very short.Take my word. If you loved volume 1 (I have worn out my copy) you may very well be disapointed with this one. It has some good stuff on it. But it isnt a fraction of what volume 1 was.BRING ON VOLUME 3 with the unplugged performance and the reunion footage!!!!!!!!

reviewText: Kissology I was pretty decent, full concerts, a few chopped TV appearences were something to pick at but this time around it gets worse. Dependin on your point of view, the Kiss movie (lol) is here in it's British theatrical version, as if the original wasnt bad enough. Why that needed to be there is anyones guess. The set picks up in 78 when the band was still huge but largely feared by parents. Edward Newman's Land Of Hype & Glory had a pretty funny doc about the band presenting them in a not so good light but its still enjoyable, or woulda been had they not decided to chop out pretty much all of it. You can find the entire clip online once again, only about 3 min is here. Most outrageous about this set is the Tom Snyder appearence where a visibly drunk Ace really stole the show and embarassed Gene and Paul who at the point had pretty much lost their zest for rock n roll and were not impressed with this on the moment fun, making it a jewel for fans. They only give you half of it. Without saying anything more, for some reason the Shandi music video is here (why not the other ones like Sure Know Something, or I Was Made For Lovin You or I Love It Loud??) Their German Countdown lipsynch appearence promoting the Unmasked album, a strange and brief clip of Peter Criss after he left from CNN and, the Kiss invades Australia doc which shows you when the band came there to tour and were very appreciated but the segment is also edited. Following that a whole show they did in AU, that covers the Unmasked era stage.Proably the best part of the set is their live performance of 3 songs off the Elder on the show Fridays. The songs are done great, and rawer than the album, theyre much better. Then we get a pointless lipsynced top of the pop appearence for I Love It Loud. Interesting to note, around this time in 82, after Ace left, there was some MORE religious backlashing cropping up again for the band even though commercially in America they were dead, this probably had something to do with heavy metal finally making a big splash with Maiden and Priest etc, and the mockingly suggestive I Love It Loud video (Knights In Satan's Serve etc). So theres some funny short news interviews where the band has a good time addressing it. This stuff shoulda been dug up and put on here, search for it online. Disc III covers the Brazil show with Vinnie, although once again, half of the show is missing and its obvious they've redited alot of it to piece together oddly. Good show though. The unmasking segment on MTV, also edited, ONLY 2 songs from the Lick It Up tour none of which include songs from the album, NOTHING from the Animalize or Asylum tours, and 5 songs from a Crazy Nights tour which arent bad. You also get a full show from the Hot In The Shade tour which is good too. MTV News segment of Carr's death, and the video for God Gave Rock N Roll To You. So all in all, there's so much more that coulda been found here, it's ridiculous. And all in all doenst say much with alll the edited stuff.The major highlights I feel, are the Fridays/Elder show and the half assed Brazil stadium gig. Don't spend a whole lot of money getting this. It's just OK.

reviewText: I guess I can't complain, there's still some great stuff on Vol. 2, however they left out a LOT this time around.  Moreso than on Vol. 1.  And the TV movie is BETTER because it's loaded with Kiss music from the solo albums and at least Gene's fire breathing 'superpower' looks more realistic than the 1988 home video release I've had for 20 years.  However, you will not see Ace sing 'Rocket Ride' in this version - that's maybe a whole 5 seconds cut early because they have to keep quiet while the blond zombie  guy walks by them.  There is a lot more in the scene involving Gene plowing through a souvenier stand that was actually quite entertaining compared to the U.S. version.  You will have to see for yourself.  The movie is also in Widescreen! That was a nice surprise.  One annoying thing is the captions can be wrong(you will have to use the captions on your TV and not on the DVD itself).  Examples: Peter's song 'Hooked on Rock & Roll' is playing and the caption reads "I was vacinated with a little needle" instead of the correct lyrics which is: "I was vacinated with a Victrola needle"(ya know, the old old record players?). And also during one concert at the very beginning it says "Paul: You wanted the best..." well, c'mon when does Paul sound that gruff? So the captions are a little spotty in accuracy, especially with song lyrics.Here's what is NOT on Vol. 2: On the Tomorrow show special there is probably about 80% of the interview.  When they cut to a commercial break, they never come back(to the best of my memory, that's where it stops but I could be wrong).  Also the music at the top of the segment and end has been changed to a live Kiss song instead of the cheesy music they used for the show.  You will NOT see Ace threaten to do his Hitler salute(which he basically did if you've seen it) and Gene saying offscreen "Don't Do It!" or the talk about Japanese Vs. German made toy helicopters or the story of Ace passed out in the hotel while the bodyguards try to explain why all his furniture was thrown out the window.  Also the entire 'Space Bear' thing has been taken out('Ace put the bear down'),  you won't see Peter talk about guns or ribbing Gene about him being 'the demon', or Tom Snyder mock Paul's comment about being a crimefighter with his hair blowing in the breeze by saying in an effeminate voice 'Hiii I fight crime' or Paul's comment about 'settling for girls' instead of women while on tour, etc. - fans should know what I'm talking if they've seen this interview before.You also will NOT see a USA channel special from 1982 called 'Radio 1990 with Lisa Robinson' which featured a lengthy interview with the band during their Creatures era.  It was really good too!  There is no visual history of Mark St. John other than a few photos on the packaging and booklet (and a 50 second easter egg on disc 3 of Gene introducing St. John to an Australian journalist.  highlight the word 'kissology' on the main menu to see it) and Paul's commentary about St. John while watching the 1987 Crazy Nights concert(go figure... that was 3 years after St. John left the band!).  There is NO visual history of the band for 1984, 1985 & 1986, no Animalize live & uncensored video or anything from Asylum other than a montage on the main menu while a live version of 'Tears are Falling' plays.  That was a slight letdown for me and just seems lazy that they would skip 3 years of their history.Having said that, there is still some cool stuff on here.  Select 'Credits' on the main menu of disc 3 and let it play and you will see Eric Carr in his hospital room video taping himself and showing his heart surgery scar from 3 days prior(and also mooning the camera).  Or Eric playing a drum solo from when he first joined in his old silver 'V' makeup design as the crowd chants 'Eric! Eric! Eric!' Also the commentary is pretty good and includes Bruce Kulick this time.  Some of what they say is in the DVD booklet, but there is a lot more if you listen to the audio version.As expected, the video quality is hit and miss much like Vol. 1 but at least there's no black and white shows(which I HATE).  The video gets oversaturated in red light during the Australia concert and you basically can't see nothing at times.  Also, Gene's blood bit is missing and at the end of Eric's drum solo you will suddenly see Gene with blood on him.  To be fair, the is mentioned on the packaging as 'God of Thunder(Incomplete)' and the first show without makeup on the Lick It Up tour just plains sucks.  Most of it is blurry.  And also I've heard that Gene did his blood thing on the first show - where is that? That would've been fun to see.  Instead we get 2 blurry songs from a very important date in 'Kisstory'.  They had room on this DVD set... Disc 1 is 1 hr 40 minutes.  A DVD can take at least 3 hrs 30 minutes... so they could've stuck some other stuff on this DVD.They could have done soooo much more with this. I'm happy but let down at the same time.  And what's with the censored Hot in the Shade concert? Paul said a lot of F and MF words but they just blank them out on here.  I hate censorship, so that ticked me off personally.  Eric Carr's drum solo during the HITS show was incredible, the way he uses monk-like voices with various drumpads - very clever.  I think they took too big a chunk of time going up to 1991 and should've maybe stopped on the Asylum era(1986).The bonus disc I got was Largo 1979, there are at least 3 or 4 clips from this same show on the "Kiss my A**" home video.  The sound is absolutely horrendous but it was cool to see Peter singing "Tossin' and Turnin" 5 months before he played his last concert with the band.Worth owning for Kiss fans.  It's true they could've made it better and they left out some really cool stuff but... at least you got this.  To me, it's worth buying just for the TV movie! I hope they they will wow us with Vol. 3.  I guess we'll find out!

reviewText: The KISSOLOGY series is for me, KISS at its very best; celebrating the bands' legacy, and properly doing justice to it, by generously loading DVD's full of top quality, vintage footage.Volume 1 (1974-1977) was just incredibly good, with 4 classic concerts from the 70's all in superb quality, visually and sonically, plus a bunch of other little gems - the standout for me being the "So It Goes" TV segment from the 1976 UK tour at the Free Trade Hall Manchester.Volume 2 was always going to struggle to live up to volume 1, simply because KISS was in it's prime on volume 1, whereas volume 2 covers a period where the band fell from grace, lost it's popularity and reinvented itself as a regular, makeup-free, hard rock band.But this set is an astounding success. Starting with the TV segment "Land of Hype and Glory", Volume 2 is off to a cracking start, showcasing how by 1978, on the Alive II tour, KISS had become the greatest rock'n'roll show in history.Then for me the highlight of the package; the movie "KISS in Attack of the Phantoms". Since watching this film in a cinema in 1980 (Odeon Theatre Chester, UK) when I was 8 years old, I have always remembered it and looked upon it as some kind of legendary classic; a movie celebrating KISS at the top. That legend was somewhat spoiled when the VHS version was officially released in the late 80's, albeit not sanctioned by KISS, as "(KISS Meets) The Phantom of the Park". The VHS version was nothing like the version I had in my heart of seeing this at the cinema in 1980; the sound quality was poor, the picture was poor and the theme music was laughable 70's cartoon music.I was astounded by the quality of "Attack of the Phantoms" on KISSOLOGY. The picture is really superb, much, much better than the VHS version, and a bootleg of "Attack" that I had on DVD. I can't imagine the effort that must have gone into tracking down the original master tape of this European theatrical version, negotiating the rights to it's release, and then restoring it to its former glory. This is what makes the KISSOLOGY series so utterly invaluable, the length to which KISS has gone out of their way, to provide real quality. The fact that you also get audio commentary from 3 of the actors in the movie, just demonstrates this even further.For this pristine copy of Phantoms alone, KISSOLOGY volume 2, is well worth every penny.I really enjoyed the rest of discs 1 and 2, the hilarious (from all but Gene's point of view) Tom Synder interview, the fantastic "Shandi" music video, Peter Criss CNN interview, and a real surprise stand-out, the lip-synched German TV performances of "She's So European" and "Talk To Me" which are both in pristine quality. Really, really wonderful stuff.The Australian documentaries are also real gems and the Sydney Showgrounds show is a excellent document of that tour. This for me is not a period where KISS was at its best. The show wasn't nearly as good as the Love Gun show and the band, albeit as hard-working as ever, never sounded as good as they had in the '70's. That said, it is wonderful that this gig has been included on KISSOLOGY, because it does provide the best possible evidence of what KISS was like at that point in their career. I also think this show is slightly better performance than the Largo 1979 show (available as a 4th bonus disc from certain retailers) and KISS made the right decision to go with this one.The Elder period is covered as well as could be expected, with the live performance of 3 songs on US TV show "Fridays". Although I love the Elder album, the band was really struggling for its identity at that time, and this is not the most enjoyable section of the KISSOLOGY series to watch. That said, the picture and sound quality is excellent; unlike the Dutch TV version of "I Love It Loud" that polishes of disc 2, which is pretty much "bootleg" quality.Disc 3 covers a period where KISS lost their way, both identity-wise, and for me musically. I have a hard time watching the Creatures concert from Rio. The Lick It Up and Crazy Nights concert footage really just shows an inferior version of the band. Still a great, hard-working rock band, but not a shadow of it's former self.  Bruce's flamboyant widdly guitar style and Eric's overly-elaborate drumming, coupled with Paul Stanley's less than stellar, or faithful, vocal renditions of the classics, just turns me off. It had to be included in the set of course - to document this period in the band's career - but it is uncomfortable at times. That's fine, thank heavens for the menu selection options !Disc 3 does however show that without makeup KISS could still put on a fantastic performance that did live up to the legend of the 70's. The Hot In The Shade show on disc 3 is excellent, Paul Stanley alone proves himself to be probably the greatest front-man of all time, and coupled with a really tight band performance, and great stage-set, KISS is finally back !The great "God Gave Rock'n'Roll To You II" promo video, as tribute to Eric Carr, is a fitting and touching way to close the set and the hospital footage of Eric after the credits have rolled, is just very moving and I think perfectly apt.I couldn't imagine giving this set any less than 5 stars. It covers the period I think suitably. There are criticisms that the Asylum/Animalize period was not covered. I personally do not miss this exclusion, and believe the make-up period is already best covered by the stellar HITS gig. However it must also be pointed out to the detractors that the Animalize Uncensored gig - is owned by Universal - address your complaints to them, not the makers of KISSOLOGY.In conclusion I would say this, the KISSOLOGY series for me is the greatest release in the history of the band. Volume 1 highlights the pinnacle of the band's career, Volume 2 does a brilliant job of covering the years it covers 1978-1991. The value for money is astounding, as is the obvious amount of time and dedication that must have gone into putting this all together in such an attractive and comprehensive set.The Hottest Band in the World - this is the evidence.
summary: Thanks KISS for another incredible chapter in the series

reviewText: Let me begin by saying that while I own and enjoy all the make-up era Kiss albums extremely, and have been listening to Kiss since I was 7 years old, I am not some sort of hard-core fan. That is, I don't automatically buy every little Kiss item that comes along, like, say, their boxed set. However, on the day I went to Best Buy to pick up The Who's "Endless Wire" album, I spotted the first volume of Kissology sitting beside it on the "new releases" shelf. I didn't really know much about it, but, after looking over the contents (like 8 hours of Kiss concert footage), I added it to my shopping basket and took it home. It did not disappoint. I've probably watched it a dozen times. I bought it a second time at Walmart to get a different "bonus" disc, and thankfully got just about all my cash money back when I sold the bonus-less discs on eBay. I didn't bother getting the 20 minute MSG concert bonus disc. You can only go so far.Anyway, having bought volume 1, I guess I'm committed to buy volume II as well. I was a bit put off by the fact that the set covers the 79-90 era, as that sounds like a whole lotta non-makeup Ace-less Kiss material. However, there is nothing to fear. Of the 3 discs, only the second half of the third is non-makeup. The rest is pure gold.I bought the Kissology II DVD set at the Walmart so I could collect the "bonus" concert disc from the Dynasty tour. Best Buy and other fine stores give you a choice of "bonus" concert discs featuring non-makeup shows, but personally I do not have interest in the non-makeup era.Some of my favorite things on the new set are the Tom Snyder interview where Ace is loaded and laughing hysterically the whole time (they only included the first half of the interview...I suppose that kinda stinks). They have some promo thing where Gene, Ace and Paul introduce Eric Carr as their new drummer, and that's pretty funny. Ace keeps cracking everyone up. For me, though, the price of admission is completely worth it for a pristine version of Kiss' appearance on the "Friday's" show, their only live performance of material from their "Music From The Elder" album. On the commentary track Paul and Gene poke fun at the twisted fans that send them letters asking them to perform "The Elder" in concert. Well, I wish they would get the message, already. "The Elder" is one of my favorite Kiss albums. They shouldn't shun it the way they do.The rest of the set is loaded with wicked awesome live footage, mostly make-up era, although there is a couple of 89-90 era shows which are hard to watch, really. Sure, the music is as sharp as ever, but Jumpin' Jehosafat, they are wearing things that even Paula Abdul would have thought of as tacky. I hope Bruce Kulick burned that suit. Damn you, 80's! Damn you! Still, they are good shows and of high quality, although I'm not sure why they completely skip over the Animalize/Asylum era. We go from the "Creatures of the Night" tour and the MTV face reveal straight to the "Crazy Nights" and "Hot in the Shade" tours. You'd think the band took 5 years off or something. Also, I wish they had included the "I Love It Loud" promo video, since it was a good one and the thing that got me into Kiss in the first place, warping my fragile little 6 year old mind back in '82, but it's strangely absent. Maybe they are planning an all music video release, but that doesn't explain why the "Shandi" promo video made the cut.The set closes with the music video for "God Gave Rock n Roll to You II" from 'Bill and Ted's Bogus Journey', which is nice, as it's Eric Carr's last appearance, and it's followed by an MTV new item regarding Eric's passing. The set ends on that sad note, which is a drag. I have search for Easter Eggs, as the first volume had a couple, but so far have come up empty.I agree with the others who have said this set should have only gone up to 1984. The late 80's stuff feels like it belongs on another set (a set I probably wouldn't buy). They could have filled it out with other things (a complete Tom Snyder, an Animalize-era show, promo videos for "I Love It Loud" and "Lick It Up"), and saved the late 80's cheese for Vol. III. A whole chunk of mid-80's "Kiss-tory" is missing.But let's not look a gift horse in the mouth. As it stands, this is a great package loaded with great vintage Kiss material. I wish all my favorite groups would collect their TV appearance and concerts in such a way.

reviewText: It seems to be incredibly hip for Kiss fans to turn up their noses at the band's glamour period - those years of "Kiss Meets the Phantom" and color coordinated costumes.  But, hey, I don't mind saying I dug it then and I dig it now.  It's campy and fun and who the heck cares?  That's all that matters.  Finally, after years of people like me who really ENJOYED Kiss in all their incarnations, this is a set of DVDs worth having.I was thrilled with Kissology Volume One and was really looking forward to Vol. Two.  I wasn't disappointed.  A lot of Kiss fans (who consider themselves somehow "purists") might point to Vol. One as the superior collection.  I beg to disagree.  For one thing, this volume has a wider variety of songs, whereas Vol. One was basically the same numbers, performed almost identically, over several tours.  An excellent collection, no doubt, but this set shows the band flexing their creative muscles and even getting a bit carried away.The centerpiece of disc one is "Kiss in Attack of the Phantoms," the theatrical release of NBC's 1979 "Kiss Meets the Phantom."  A few scenes that had gone unused in the U.S. tele-movie are here and I have to admit, this film is a riot.  It's not Coppolla, but it ain't supposed to be!  Come on, folks!  We're talking about Kiss fighting robot monkey men in an amusement park!  It's just fun.  The real treat of this version of the movie is that much of the original music used in the American version has been replaced with songs from the solo albums.  The effect is very retro, but very nice.The complete concert from Sydney is just priceless. Seeing Eric Carr in action again is a moving experience.  And the band, replete in all their "Xanadu" costumes, manage to rock every bit as hard as when they wore the more credible (?) black leather in the Cobo Hall in 1975.A huge treat is the complete performances from ABC's short-lived "Fridays" show, the only known live performances of The Elder material.  This whole DVD set is worth it just for Ace's guitar on "The Oath."  The guy could burn back then, even as he made his exit from the band.  I don't care how many concert T-Shirt-wearing-potbellied purists disagree, this stuff was good.I would have liked to have seen more of the concert in Rio De Janeiro, from the "Creatures of the Night" tour, particularly Gene's bass solo.  But that's nitpicking.  The footage from the first non-make-up show in Lisbon is grainy - with an almost bootleg quality to it - but that only adds to the charm.  And the full set from the "Hot in the Shade" Tour proves, I think, that Kiss are a group of stellar musicians with some seriously great music.As a side note, if you are one of the lucky few to receive a copy with the bonus "1979 Largo" disc, you'll be happy to notice that the grainy footage (some of which is evident in previous compilations) has been somewhat cleaned up.If you're a Kiss fan, buy this!!  Buy it now!!
summary: Secure enough to admit I dig it!

reviewText: I reviewed this dvd before it was released and some people thought that was unfair, since it wasn't out yet. So, I will give another review based on actually watching it. First of all, it was pretty much what i expected. Disk 1 starts out with a documentary about the band and the hype behind them. It's o.k. but you can tell they don't really like the band. Next is the movie "kiss in attack of the phantoms". I'm very pleased with the widescreen version of the movie. I did notice this european version is about 10 minutes shorter than the U.S. version. In the U.S. version, there was funky generic music used in a lot of the scenes. Most of this music is replaced with music from the solo albums! During the fight with the robots, they play "new york groove". The picture is very clear and in great shape. Take the movie for what it is: a superhero comedy! Disk 1 ends with the Tom Snyder show. This was just great. I wish they had shown the whole thing. Anyway, the whole interview is all about Ace Frehley! Gene and Paul are trying to give a serious interview and Ace keeps cracking jokes. All through the interview, you see Gene getting mad and it looks like he wants to rip his head off! Ace was oviously stoned or drunk out of his mind!Disk 2 starts out with the "shandi" video. Then there's the interview with Peter Criss after he was fired. In the interview, he says he left the band, but that's not what Gene said. Next, there's "unmasked" video performances. Then, Kiss invade Sydney documentary, which is only about 5 minutes. The concert itself it very good. Ace Frehley really does well here. He sings 3 songs, including "new york groove". The only flaw in the concert is after they do "love gun", the drum solo for "god of thunder" starts up and you only get the end part of the song. After the concert, you get their "friday's" appearance where they perform "music from the elder". This is actually really good quality. Then they perform "I love it loud" on top of the pops. This isn't very good quality. The picture is very poor.Disk 3 starts off with the concert from rio. I'm glad they included this footage, however, quality isn't very good. After every song, the concert has been edited so the next song starts immediately after the next. There's no talking and the 7 songs they do is over in 25 minutes! The DVD says the concert ends with "rock and roll all nite". However, it ends with "black diamond". This really didn't matter to me because every other concert has "rock and roll all nite" in it anyway! Next, the MTV unmasking is included here and Gene and Paul do all the talking! Do you really think Gene would have let Vinnie Vincent talk? Then the first ever appearance of them without makeup in concert is next. This footage,in Portugal, isn't very good quality either. I would like to note that this is probably why no footage from the ASYLUM tour is included. Even though Kiss record all their concerts, most of the old footage just isn't good enough for a video release. Kiss probably had concerts that they considered really good and kept them in good shape. The other stuff they felt was unworthy, they let it go to waste. Video tape does go bad after awhile and a lot of that old stuff just wasn't preserved very well!Next, we get a few songs from the "crazy nights" tour. The quality is acually pretty good. The highligh is a live version of "reason to live". which should have been a bigger hit in the U.S.Then we have the "hot in the shade" concert which is just awesome! This concert alone is the main reason to purchase Kissology 2! It's just a great mix of classic 70's Kiss along with their big 80's hits! At this point of their career, Kiss was really fired up and this performance is probably one of their best ever! Sadly the dvd ends with MTV saying that Eric Carr has passed away. Truely, he was very important to kiss and I believe he was just as good as Peter Criss! That is why I wanted the "live at the ritz" bonus disk. It has more footage of the crazy nights tour. The sound is fine but the video is shaky. I will say there is one funny part and it comes while the band performs "crazy crazy nights". As the song starts, it's apparent Paul doesn't have the right guitar to do the song, so the song sounds out of key. One of the crewmembers actually comes onstage and hands him another guitar. It turns out this still isn't the right guitar either! Paul looks confused! The band continues to play the song and the solo finally arrives. Bruce Kulick actually plays a longer solo so Paul can find the right guitar! When Paul shows back up on stage, he just goes on with the rest of the song as if nothing had happened! It's kinda like when Gene forgets the lyrics to songs!The rest of disk 3 is the video to "god gave rock and roll to you II" and it is dedicated to the life of Eric Carr. Be sure to watch all the way through the credits to see the bonus video of Eric Carr in a hospital bed. He oviously recorded it himself and had just had heart surgery. In the video he says he's excited to get well and get back to the band. Sadly, this did not happen and Eric went into a coma soon afterwards. This whole second volume of the Kissology should be dedicated to probably the best drummer kiss ever had. Also disk 3 has a hidden bonus nugget of a Mark St. John interview, the Kiss guitarist who played on "Animalize". He died earlier this year.So, overall this is a very good set and if you're real Kiss fan, you will enjoy!

reviewText: KISSology Vol. 1 was one of the greatest music DVD's ever released.  A tremendous collection of great, vintage KISS concerts and TV apperances, KISSology really raised the bar when it comes to career retrospectives on DVD.Now, KISS is releasing (or has released, depending on when you read this), the 2nd volume in the KISSology series, covering 1978-1991.  It's got almost everything from that era that fans have wanted on DVD (almost, there are some exceptions) - The Land of Hype and Glory, The Tomorrow Show with Tom Snyder (Ace is a RIOT), Australia 1980, FRIDAYS (!!!), Brazil 1983, a couple songs from the first post-makeup concert, and a complete concert from one of their greatest tours ever - the Hot In The Shade tour!  Leon Sphinx was pretty darned cool as the centerpiece, and the band was ON!There are some other goodies, but the one I intentionally left out until now is KISS in ATTACK OF THE PHANTOMS - the European theatrical version of KISS Meets the Phantom of the Park.  Supposedly there are scenes cut from the US version, and the score is different in parts as well.  This will be a lot of fun to watch - as long as you "get it."  It's a 70's campy TV movie, and for that time and genre it is a lot of fun.The DVD ends with the passing of the great Eric Carr (I had the opportunity to meet him in 1990 - he truly was a great guy, and he is very much missed), leaving the Revenge era for Vol. 3.Could there be more on there from the 80's?  Animalize Live Uncensored is a glaring omission, as is anything from the entertaining Asylum tour, but this is still one heck of a tracklisting and another great release!UPDATE: After watching the entire set a few things stand out.  1.) The Australia show from 1980 was fantastic.  The band was MUCH tighter than the previous year on the Dynasty tour (I got each set, and after watching the Largo disc it was like night and day).  2.) The Brazil 1983 show was heavily edited by the TV network that aired it, and as such a few songs have been shortened in this presentation.  3.) They should have included more songs from the Philadelphia 1987 show.  The band was ON, and it would have been nice to have more of this show.  4.) The 1990 Hot in the Shade show is edited.  "Rise To It," is missing - they show the bluesy intro, but skip the song.  WTF?  Eric Carr's drum solo is also edited, but this is understandable - he sampled the intro to the Who's "Who Are You," and that becomes a rights issue.  That part of the solo is gone.  Interestingly enough, it was edited out so well that you wouldn't notice it isn't there if you didn't know.  5.) The Land of Hype and Glory is edited far too short, and the Tom Snyder appearance is cut in half (Space Bear is MIA).But, keep in mind - everything that IS here is VERY cool.  The footage from Fridays is pristine!  The commentary throughout is very good as well, and even Bruce gets in on the commentary action!  (Way to go Bruce!)  The Detroit 1990 show is a great performance from a GREAT tour with a GREAT stage set.  A tour that Paul and Gene still rank as one of their best ever.  This set is a very, very solid continuation of what they started with Vol. 1.  Could it have been better?  Yes.  But it is still a great set if you go by what is included rather than what is left out.Also - ATTACK OF THE PHANTOMS is practically a different movie from Phantom of the Park.  Previously unused scenes, extended scenes, music from the solo albums as part of the score, and a rearranged order of what happens in the movie.  Some of these things are HUGELY positive (added scenes and dialogue is a big improvement), but some are detrimental (taking events out of order hurts the movie as some things make even LESS sense here).  ATTACK is also in anamorphic widescreen, cropped from the original 4:3 TV format (although the cropping is usually done very well).There is also a very reverential tone towards the late Eric Carr.  Eric was a really, really nice guy. (Everyone who met him says that - I met him as well, and he was just REALLY nice and had no inflated "Rock Star Ego."  In the commentary Paul hints at regrets at how things unfolded as Eric was dying in 1991.  And watch through the credits at the end.  In one way it's hard to watch this bonus, but in another it is a nice tribute - and a slight glimpse of Eric's sense of humor and how much he cared about the fans.)Bottom line?  If you're a serious fan, you've got to have it in your collection.  If you're just a casual fan you should still get it since the price is right for what you get and the set is a lot of fun to watch.

reviewText: I'm one of those rare dinosaurs that saw kiss in small clubs like Joint In The Woods in 73, was an instant fan, ran the first KISS fanzine "Kisser" with a friend (Hi Randy), maintained a COMPLETE collection, met the band, and followed them fervently till 1980, when the merchandising simply burned me out. My point being, I have credentials.The history on much of this DVD material is as follows. Kiss ex-manager Bill Aucoin had all the Kiss stuff in a big warehouse. Circa 1987, for reasons personal, he needed money, and speaking with Ace, offered it all for $100,000. Ace didn't want it, and since he was not particularly fond of Gene and Paul, he didn't mention it to them. Enter two fans that met Ace, Al and Gary. They mortgaged a house, paid Aucoin, rented two tractor trailers, and picked up all the stuff. They then hosted numerous killer Kiss conventions. THAT's the source of all the copies of the material on this DVD, which was eventually copied ad nauseum. Well, Gene & Paul eventually found out, had the cops raid an Al/Gary convention, and confiscated everything as "stolen merchandise". Kiss then sponsored it's own conventions, ultimately auctioned all the costumes, and have now funneled the video stuff to be included in Kissology DVD's. THAT's why this material is not new to real fans.So, anyway, the actual material. The upside is, you get a first generation, clean copy, of some really great Kiss video. The downside,there are some NASTY cuts. Land Of Hype And Glory is only an excerpt. Too bad cause it was a great show. But the biggest SIN, is that the Tom Snyder show appearance is CUT IN HALF. Any fan will tell you that the single most entertaining piece of Kiss video is the Tom Syder show. This is the one video that even non-Kiss fans appreciate. Ace is a riot! He was drunk and tripping, laughing hysterically, abducted Tom's mascot teddy bear, and put his costume pieces on the bear. Hilarious, but you won't see it, cause it's in the half they cut. It's confounding. So, if you're a big fan, yes this is a great DVD, but don't think you can toss your old VHS bootlegs. Sadly, not yet.Visually, Kiss can't be topped. Historically, they saw Alice Cooper in 72 and said "If one guy in makeup is this big, what if all four of us wore makeup". Kiss pioneered flames, explosions, and moving stage pieces. Today, these things are staples with metal bands and the like, but Kiss literally started it. In the early days, Kiss were quite the underground cult band. Greasepaint, leather, and flames, wrapped in mystery. Nobody knew their true identity for several years. The teenybopper stuff only started with the Destroyer tour in 76.Musically, nobody does straight ahead hard rock better than Kiss. I'm not talking metal, or thrash, but plain old crunchy driving hard rock.And another thing, attitudinally, Gene and Paul were always in one camp, and Ace & Peter in another. Historically, the two camps always fought, and both sides had valid points. Originally each band member contractually "owned a letter" in KISS. Eventually, Ace & Peter sold their letters to Gene and Paul. First Peter, which left Ace to be out-voted on band conflicts, eventually causing Ace to quit as well. Since then, Gene & Paul have been petty about making sure they get majority coverage, and looking best, in everything Kiss, marginalizing Ace & Peter, and sometimes showing them in unfavorable light. I love KISS, all of the original four (and Eric, he's earned it), but I sure wish Gene & Paul could check their ego some, and represent the whole band equally, for the sake of the fans. Gene! Paul! The real fans know the score. And we talk about it. There's a consensus. We want you guys to all play nice, get along, and share the spotlight equally. Ya, Ace & Peter have issues, but so do you. Kiss is too good to be sullied by petty infighting, egos, money, and other BS.KISS ROCKS !

reviewText: I'm 44 and have been a KISS fan since I was 14. This is a very good collection of good stuff.  I give it 4 instead of 5 stars, because this is not my favorite period of Kisstory, and they shortened the Snyder and Newman broadcasts which is too bad (but not unforgivable).Fans will, naturally, complain of omissions, and they do exist - no footage of tours for the 3 albums between Creatures of the Night and Crazy Nights.  The Tom Snyder interview (which is excellent and clearly the best, most candid, personal interview you will EVER see with the original foursome) has only the first ten minutes, thereby leaving out most of the material that might be considered "objectionable to posterity" -- Ace and Paul admitting to drugs, booze, and underage girls, Peter speaking about gun collecting and the gangster fascination.  However, the first ten minutes ARE dynamite, and should lay to rest ANY contentions that Gene Simmons edited them to remove Ace's highpoints.  They kept the first ten minutes exactly as broadcast, and Gene and Paul do voiceover commentaries to explain that Ace was, in fact, going over very well but that they were always worried that he might implode.My biggest surprise was "Attack of the Phantoms," which was not NEARLY as wretched as I remembered/imagined it to be. I mean, it's a 70s made-for-TV-movie -- remember them?  They all sucked.  But, considering the way KISS themselves remember it, they really don't come off looking all that bad.  Frankly, the script gives them VERY little dialogue, so they didn't have much room to screw it up.  I don't think they made themselves look like fools at all.  It's just a cheesy TV movie.  The actors' commentary was very interesting, so check it out.  And the movie makes, for the time, excellent and abundant use of the solo albums for soundtrack music.I wouldn't say I enjoyed "Attack of the Phantoms" for its own sake, but it wasn't breath-takingly, history-makingly horrible, is my point.  And, of course, very interesting to watch if you're a KISS fan, which I expect anyone who's read this far must be.I say, get this DVD set.  It's inevitable that you will, naturally.  And you'll have a lot of fun.  The price is a good value.

reviewText: Granted, there are many things that could have made this set better:  The FULL Tom Snyder interview instead of a fraction of it, more promo footage, a segment on Mark St. John (and since he passed recently, it would at least have been noble and polite to at least pay SOME sort of tribute to the guy -- would have taken some last-minute production scrambling, but they could have done it if they wanted to badly enough), etc. -- Granted, there is a brief snippet of him in an Easter Egg and a brief mention of him in a commentary, neither of which feature is even listed on the contents page.But what there is is generally very satisfying.  Some die-hard KISS fans who have the vast majority of this stuff on bootleg already have bemoaned the fact that they didn't get much new material here.  But the vast majority of the casual-to-heavy fans do NOT already have this material in bootleg form, and it is a treat for us to see it.There are extensive periods in the band's 1983-1986 history that are barely touched on or even ignored, but those years fell between more major salient events and were the easiest eras to omit and still maintain a sense of "flow" in the presented chronology.Example:  The make-up comes off in 1983, so we see the last show IN make-up and the first show OUT of make-up.  That's the right idea.  The next few years were just a series of tours that didn't see any major milestones or events (barring Kulick replacing Norton, who replaced Vincent -- the band apparently is still uncomfortable discussing that era of rotating guitarists, so let them have their way on this one.  If we pressured them to get more detailed about it, they'd still give us the same watered-down version of the events so why beat your head against the wall over it?).Then they jump to the "Crazy Nights" tour probably because it has more visually interesting footage.  The costumes during the "Asylum" era were, as Gene admits, embarrassing.  So they were probably happy to omit that era altogether.  I don't know anyone who necessarily JUMPS at the chance to show off old video and pics of himself that are embarrassing and cringe-inducing, so why would we expect these guys to do it?  Personal preference on their part, an we're all entitled to do the same thing.The next salient event was the Hot In The Shade tour, notable not only for a re-invigorated band playing from their full catalog of songs, but also for it being Carr's last tour.  See?  The DVD hits the highlights and salient events, glosses over or ignores a few years where the bumps in the road aren't necessarily worth revisiting for them, and yet the DVD package still is chock full of stuff to see.The "Animalize: Uncensored" concert IS on DVD, by the way.  I found it at Best Buy years ago as an import.  It is subtitled in Portuguese.KISS left a bit of history out, but they kept a LOT in.  The "Fridays" stuff is great  --  I saw that episode on TV back during its first run, and I never thought I'd get to see it again.But between KISSOLOGY 1 and 2 and their bonus discs, the KISS Alive 4 with Symphony DVD (which has rapid-fire editing that gives me a headache), the "Rock the Nation" DVD, and the assorted long-form videos that they've released since 1987, KISS has given us TONS and TONS and TONS and TONS of goodies for home video, perhaps more than any other band EVER!  That alone is grounds for some appreciation and perhaps even grounds to tell the complainers to shut the heck up.The more they release for us, the more some of you moan and complain about what they didn't include.  Unless Gene and Paul personally hand you a key to their vaults, you will NEVER see everything.  It just isn't gonna happen.  Nor should it.There could be all sorts of logical and sensible reasons why certain footage isn't included, but that isn't good enough for some people.  They have to know WHY it wasn't included.  I get curious about that too, but I'm not going to let that spoil my enjoyment of what I have or allow it to stir up resentment because they didn't bombard me with every last second of footage from everything they ever shot.Sure, it would be great to get EVERYTHING, but that would be overkill and ultimately a bit saddening.  To know you have EVERYTHING and that there is nothing else left to see, well....  that ultimately leads to a kind of boredom.It might even be too much like the Twilight Zone episode entitled "A Nice Place to Visit".  Google that to see what I mean.This DVD does not include every last inch of film footage shot of them between 1978 and 1991.  Sorry gang, but it doesn't.  But it includes HOURS AND HOURS AND HOURS of stuff I would never see if they didn't release this DVD, so I'm delighted to have it.And I'm sure you would/will be too.
summary: Doesn't have everything, but hits where it should.

reviewText: There's lot of good stuff here on the second installment of this KISSology series. I'm a die-hard, hard core KISS fan, but I can still call them like I see them. I'll go over a few likes and dislikes.At this point I am now convinced there is absolutly no live footage of Mark St. John. I know he played two and a half shows with KISS. If there is footage, no one is giving it up. All this DVD has to offer representing Mark St. John is a quick Easter egg interview.The most blatant thing about this DVD set that I did not like was the Tom Snyder interview. I've had it on tape for years and I love it. I don't know what is funnier, Ace's drunken laughing or Gene's look of aggravation as he is being constantly intrupted. This is not anywhere close to being the complete interview. Tom Snyder cuts to a commercial break and never comes back. This was a huge disappointment. This interview was a train wreck as soon as the cameras started rolling. A lot of good humor was missed by cutting this. I bought my video at a KISS convention, but you can see it in it's entirty on YouTube.The European version of "KISS Meets the Phantom of the Park" is far superior to the store bought VHS tape I have. I love the fact that there is so much extra footage, and by adding KISS music in where Hanna-Barberra originally had their disco music, makes this movie so much more enjoyable. I enjoyed the movie more this time around than I ever have before in my life and I've seen this movie at least 30 times.The Elder will always be debatable concerning KISS fans. The Elder footage is embarrassing for me, but it is interesting. But what was Paul thinking with that purple headband?I was glad to see Vinnie Vincent footage. Say what you want, he is an incredible guitarist and in a way he saved KISS from themselves. I already had the RIO show which is great because I love Vinnie's makeup. I would have rather seen the entire Lick it Up show instead of just two songs though. The first concert without makeup should have been a full show.I say this because watching Bruce Kulick is painful. He is a very talented guitarist. I play guitar and I know he is good, much better than me, but the man had no persona. Ace is the only KISS lead guitarist in my opinion. Vinnie was an interesting time from a fan's view point. Mark we will never know about, but Bruce was just boring. He could play the parts on guitar, but he always looked so uncomfortable on stage. Did the guy ever do a spotlight solo in KISS? I've never seen it.A lot of time was skipped in this DVD. Animalize and Asylum was all but forgotten. Where was the Animalize show from Detroit?? I lost my tape years ago and have not seen it in over 15 years. I would have prefered an Animalize show or a Asylum show over Crazy Nights.I hated the Crazy Nights period of KISS, it was a terrible album and KISS trying to be Bon Jovi was the low point of their career. Thank God they rebounded with the Hot in the Shade Tour. But my biggest disappointment of this whole set was Animalize and Asylum being totally glossed over.I was glad to see the three music videos from Unmasked. That was an album I always did like, but rarely admit. The Austrailia show was great too. It was the first time I've ever seen it without the run numbers at the bottom of the screen.The bonus disc I got with my package was the Crazy Nights tour from Budakon. I would have much preferred the Largo Show. I already have that on tape too, but it would have been nice to have on DVD.I prefer the first KISSOLOGY only because that is my favorite period of KISS. If you are in the KISS Army like me, you will get this set and enjoy it.
summary: Hit and miss collection, but very satisfying

reviewText: I went to Wal-Mart to buy KISSology 2 with the Largo Bonus disc. I was surprised that on day 3 of the release there were still 2 on the front display shelf for all to see. When I told the cashier that I was surprised that they weren't sold out he commented that the Garth Brooks concert dvd was one of their quicker sells. Garth Brooks - bwahaha! I guess for this reason I'm lucky that I live in a country music state.I've loved KISS since 1978, and I've probably played the Alive 1 & 2 albums (yes albums!) more than anyone on the planet. I had friends over at the house and we played pool all day and listened to the albums over and over. I would "play guitar" with my pool stick in between shots, and had all the Ace Frehley rifts down and could "play sync" them with realism. This was before I knew of anything called lip syncing, and it wasn't widely heard of to the public and became a more popular term in the 80s. I was really disappointed when KISS went commercial in 1979 and 1980 with Dynasty and Unmasked to change their style and appeal to the masses, but have grown into a few of those songs over the years. I skipped over the Elder. Creatures of the Night brought me back full time into the KISS Army in 1982, but I was shocked and disappointed again when the makeup was removed in 1983. It didn't help when they did the ugly cavemen look in the Lick It Up video. Later I borrowed the Lick It Up and Animalize cassette tapes from a friend back in the day and played them for a while. I never saw or owned a bootleg concert video, and no I didn't live in a cave - I lived on an island called Hawaii. This review comes from a person who was not spoiled by having any bootlegs so I can say that watching this was a wonderful experience.Finally, on to the review: Attack of the Phantoms is a nice crisp widescreen production, and it was a little different from the USA version I recorded off the TV. There were a few additional scenes, and one that was missing or replaced. The part where Devereau draws a red circle on a closeup photo of Gene and says "So you're the demon, hmmm?" was missing. Looks like they replaced it with Sam bringing in a rack of photos of the group. An additional part I noticed was the worried girl looking around by the red volkswagon after losing her boyfriend for what - 5 minutes? I just found out that cartoony music was subbed in for the TV version to be more kid-friendly. Instead of KISS songs they played 70's Starsky and Hutch type action music during action scenes on my TV version. It was nice to see that this cd had the KISS music intact. When the security guards were in the shed "Almost Human" was played, and during the fighting with the white apes "New York Groove" was played. More KISS songs instead of 70's "wacka-dooda-wacka" made the production seem less cheezy - if that's even possible.The Tom Snyder interview was great, despite what many are saying. It is the first half of it and the part I thought was best. I didn't care for Peter talking about his gun collection or Ace playing with the teddy bear which I thought was overkill. Saw that part on YouTube and that was enough.The Rio concert was awesome and surreal with that huge crowd, but I was wondering why some of the songs were sliced up. On one song they began with Eric's drum solo and then I got the ending of God of Thunder. Where was the beginning? Gene had blood on his face but I missed the spitting. Also the first few verses of Cold Gin was missing. More puzzling than anything and leads me to believe that the cameramen had originally forgot to press record in these cases.A KISS mini booklet was included with photos and exerpts on what they thought of each era's features - including their feelings on the Tom Snyder interview. A replica of a KISS ticket at Magic Mountain was also included.The Largo bonus disc was okay, and I wanted to get that one as I never was a big fan of the non-makeup days. I wanted to see another "War Machine" live performance with either of the other 2 bonuses but the makeup concert was the deciding vote. The biggest problem I have with the Largo bonus CD was that during the long shots there are horizontal video lines on the screen which points to cheap recording.I would have liked to have seen more mid-80s stuff like the Animalize concert and feel that maybe they should've started the 90s in Volume 3. Not really complaining, just shocked at the quick jump in years and I was never into the Crazy Nights and other commercialized music around that time. Still, very much worth the purchase price for me and worthy of 5 solid stars.I will not be getting Kissology 3, as I am not a fan of any of the replacement "actors". Thayer and Singer look bogus with the makeup. Their faces are so wide that it looks wrong, like they are wearing oversized KISS Halloween masks. Miss you Ace, Peter, and Eric.

reviewText: To me, the 1978-82 period of KISS is the most intriguing.  I like the diversity of the solo albums, the disco-esque "Dynasty," the hard rocking "Creatures of the Night."  I absolutely LOVE "Music: From the Elder" (I don't care what others, including Paul Stanley and Gene Simmons say, I think it is a brilliant masterpiece) and I kind of sort of like "Unmasked" ("Shandi" is good, and the cover is cool). This chapter of Kissology is, obviously, of great interest to me.  Most of this material has been available unofficially for years, but it is nice to have it on DVD quality.  To me, the star attraction that got my attention when looking at the content listing on the back of the box was "KISS in Attack of the Phantoms."I've always known the film as "KISS Meets the Phantom of the Park."  I've had the late 1980s VHS release since, probably, the late '80s, but the version here if ultra cool.  There is extra concert footage and special effects and, even better, they've dubbed in tracks from all four of the KISS solo albums.  That makes so much sense!  More KISS music!  Some of the tracks work very well with the selected scenes in the film.  The intro to "Radioactive" when the Gene clone comes out to attack the park guards and an unsuspecting drink stand, "Mr. Make Believe" as Abner Devereaux is told, basically, to retire, "Hold Me, Touch Me (Think of Me When We're Apart)" when Melissa leaves the park without Sam and finds his retro VW bug, and Paul's "Love in Chains" when KISS was in the Chamber of Thrills. All the solo records are well-represented.  It was fun just identifying all the songs. (I won't give them all away, but did you catch the opening to "Burning Up with Fever"?)There are also scenes I don't remember seeing in my VHS copy, like when Sam comes in with the photographs he took of KISS and the security office scene where the bullies turned Bicentennial robots show up (and "Almost Human" is played).  There are small details I remember from the VHS version that were cut here (like when the bullies fell through the chutes in the Chamber of Thrills), but no big deal.The other television clips and live footage is nice, but I'm disappointed that much of it is edited.  "The Tomorrow Show with Tom Snyder" where Ace was plastered is laugh-out-loud hilarious, but is not complete.  The CNN Peter Criss interview is cut before they reveal his non-makeup face (quick! put the makeup back on!).  The MTV unmasking special is cut.  I know these things are available on unofficial releases, but I don't have them, so I've never seen the complete interviews.  Also, they include the video for "Shandi," but why not "I Was Made For Loving You" and "Sure Know Something"?  There was other Elder TV footage that could have been included, too, like their appearance on "Flo and Eddie." I know they can't include everything and there is copyright stuff with which to deal, but I personally would rather have more television promos, interviews, appearances, and videos that I don't need to adjust the tracking constantly on unofficial videos than all the concert footage that could be included on a different DVD.  The extra DVD is from the Dynasty tour: check out Paul missing a verse in "Move On." You can pick which track you want to see which is cool, but it doesn't include (probably mercifully) "King of the  Nighttime World" where Ace hit a really bad note and Peter completing flubbing up "Beth."  One who sees the whole concert can tell KISS was close to their transitional period.To end on a positive note, the audio commentary is great (click "Set Up" on the menu page). It has very interesting (and sometimes funny) quotes from Paul, Gene, Ace, and Bruce Kulick about the material on the DVDs (some of the quotes are in the booklet). Gene on the Tom Snyder interview: "I thought we were going to come on as big bad superstars, and the result is kind of a grumpy old man who used to stick his tongue out and a bombed guitar player." There are also some touching quotes about the late, great Eric Carr. The part at the end of the credits where Eric is in the hospital bed after his open-heart surgery is downright spooky. He looks happy and healthy in the film, but he must have suffered so much. A must for the KISS fan, I only wish it was a more complete documentary.
summary: "Let's stop this pussy-footing around"--Peter Criss in KISS Meets the Phantom of the Park

reviewText: Kissology Volume II (1978 - 1991) has a lot of great footage that most Kiss fans will love.  At first I really enjoyed watching it.  Then it began to depress me.  Just as Kissology Volume I (1974 - 1979) shows the rise of Kiss, Kissology Volume II (1978 - 1991) shows the decline of Kiss.  Kissology Volume II starts with footage of Kiss at their over-the-top height, including the European release of Kiss Meets The Phantom of the Park.  It then shows, with footage including full concerts, how Kiss devolved through their Unmasked, Elder and Creature eras.  Kiss takes the makeup off and, as much as many fans will hate hearing this and as much as I myself liked the Eric Carr and Bruce Kulick lineup, Kiss became not that different from most other hair metal acts from the 1980's.  Kissology Volume II then ends with Eric Carr's death.  Regarding the DVD itself, I think more could have been fitted into the first DVD in Kissology Volume II (i.e.: the 1979 Largo concert could have been added to it instead of being a bonus DVD) and the first DVD in Kissology Volume II really belonged more with Kissology Volume I.  That would have made them Kissology Volume I, The Originals (1974 - 1979) and Kissology Volume II, The Eric Carr Years (1980 - 1991), which would have made Kissology Volume II an even better tribute to Eric Carr.  Regardless of how they were packaged, the content of both DVD's is great and both are definitely must haves for any Kiss fan.  I just wish the content of Kissology Volume II didn't leave me feeling depressed as a fan about how far Kiss strayed from their original uniqueness.
summary: The decline of Kiss.  Could have been packaged better with Volume I.

reviewText: I've been a KISS fan for many many years.  Most of the material that's included in this set I've seen before, and many times.  However, its so awesome to have it all on one DVD, officially released, and remastered.  The sound and picture quality are mostly really good (considering some of the source material).  The performances are really enjoyable as well.  I'm really bummed that only half the Tom Snyder interview is included as that is one of the klassic KISS moments.  I was so looking forward to seeing Space Bear again.  I would also have liked a little more footage of Vinnie, and it would have been really terrific if there was any live footage at all with Mark St. John (especially as he has now passed on as well).However, there are many inclusions here that I'm excited about, like the performance of the three ELDER songs on "Fridays", the complete Syndey concert, etc.The best thing about this collection, though, is that it follows the career of drummer Eric Carr from the time he joined the band up 'til his death in 1991.  For Carr fans, this truly is a visaul and aural feast.  We see him getting introduced by the band to the Australian audience, we see him on various tours with the band (both with make up and without), and best of all we get complete drum solos (well, nearly complete; read the featured reviews for that explanation) from both his first and his final tour with KISS, showing his growth as a drummer and the evolution in his approach to soloing over the 11 years he was in the band.  The package is capped off with MTV's announcement of his passing and the video of "God Gave Rock'n'Roll To You", his final performance with the band.One of the best surprises on the set comes in one of the menus.  Each of the menus and sub-menus includes video footage not available anyhwere else.  One of the sub-menus on Disk Two features performance footage of Eric in his original "fox" make up -- not the familiar design that's seen on the cover of CREATURES OF THE NIGHT, but the original design which was only seen in a very few photos, including the first batch of press photos the band did with Carr.The most shocking and heartbreaking thing that got included in this set --  its not listed in the menu, its at the end of the credits on Disk 3 -- is a video that Eric made in his hospital bed a couple of days after his open heart surgery.  Oh man....I cried the first time I saw that.  I didn't even know anything like that existed. Its actually rather spooky and kind of creepy to watch this short vid.  Even though his mood is upbeat and he's joking around in true Carr fashion, there's a sadness to it.  Be prepared when you watch it .... but do watch it.I was a huge Eric fan right from day one. When the first photos of him with the band were released, I wrote him a letter.  Couple months later, I got a hand-written letter back from him from Frankfurt, where KISS was touring.  I later met him once in FL.  When you hear people say or read in these reviews what a great, nice guy Eric was....that's no exaggeration.  Eric Carr was a super guy, a really warm, loving human being who really loved his fans, and his fans loved him.  I was devastated when he passed away three days after my birthday (and on the same day as Freddie Mercury, god what a horrible day).  I will always miss him and will always be his fan.Thanks to KISS for making this second volume of KISSOLOGY such a treat for Eric's fans.  What a great package....it not only chronicles KISS's career throughout the 80s, but also the career of my favourite drummer.  Long live Eric Carr.
summary: A Great Memorial to Eric Carr

reviewText: This was when KISS were going through several serious changes.  The first disc begins with a filmmaker talking about KISS in a way that isn't true to KISS. In between these two short films is the KISS movie.  The movie was an okay film, but if you want a KISS movie, see Detroit Rock City, which is not really a KISS movie, but it's still good.The second disc begins with the loss of Peter Criss, and the addition of Eric Carr.  This was when KISS were starting to go down as a band, but the film of their performance in Australia, during the tour where they were really treated like royalty was very special.  I feel that the film quality wasn't that good, and I'm guessing that they replaced some of the footage.  It also skips the beginning of "God of Thunder," but it shows Eric Carr's killer drum solo.  After the big Australian show, it shows KISS doing songs from the Elder on a TV show, and later, a promotional film for "I Love it Loud," their single from Creatures of the Night.The second disc begins with them on their Creatures of the Night tour.  It's only about twenty minutes of the show.  However, it shows how KISS were not big in their own country, but people had been waiting years to see them, and although it wasn't their line-up with Peter Criss and Ace Frehley, it shows how they were worth the wait.  This is followed by KISS first showing their true faces, and then their first unmasked show, promoted as a masked show because they hadn't planned on unmasking when scheduling the show.  After that is excerpts from a later tour, which wasn't the biggest tour.  The DVD ends with the tour where KISS really realized their importance, and entered the stage, truly proud of their legacy.  This tour was also their big comeback tour, yet it was sadly the last one with Eric Carr, who died of cancer.  The DVD ends with a special tribute to Eric Carr.Volume three picks up from where this one leaves off.

reviewText: "Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991",fortunately,picks right up on where "KISS:Kissology--The Ultimate KISS Collection,Vol. 1:1974-1977" left off. A great treat-correct? Correct!!!! Let's take a closer look at "Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991" has to offer,shall we?CONCERTS:These concerts(one representing the KISS line-up of Gene Simmons,Paul Stanley,Ace Frehley,and Eric Carr,two representing the line-ups of Gene Simmons,Paul Stanley,Eric Carr,and Vinnie Vincent and Gene Simmons,Paul Stanley,Eric Carr,and Bruce Kulick)are the heart and soul of"Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991". They have the power and energy of any KISS concert(no matter how many line-ups and musical changes the band went through!),offer klassic KISS songs live and at their best,and do an ideal job at showing who the men onstage really are/were as musicians.THE EUROPEAN VERSION OF KISS MEETS THE PHANTHOM OF THE PARK:KISS IN ATTACK OF THE PHANTHOMS:Corny? Absolutely. But,that doesn't stop the fun and "laughter". That doesn't change a rare gem being available on "Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991",either!!!!!!!TELEVISION FOOTAGE:From regular,known/unkown footage to the best known and rarest(the CNN interview with Peter Criss that was conducted the same year that Criss was fired from KISS,KISS unmasking on MTV for the first time ***ever*** in September 1983,and the "Day in Rock" "special" that was once used to announce the death of Eric Carr the day after his passing),KISS fans can dig into KISS on television--enjoying the rare stuff,and ***finally*** having the rare footage that all of us would have liked to own for years!!!!!MUSIC VIDEOS:It may just be the videos for "Shandi" and "God Gave Rock 'N' Roll To You II". But,they are great videos that are now just as easy to find as the "Heaven's On Fire" and "Tears Are Falling" videos,and make sure that "Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991" doesn't end the day being incomplete!!!!!BOOKLET:Colored photos,notes on the tracks from either Gene Simmons,Paul Stanley,Ace Frehley,and/or Bruce Kulick,this booklet is just as much of a fun treat as it is informative.COMMENTARIES:The three discs of "Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991" contain a commentary,all three of which were recorded by Gene Simmons,Paul Stanley,and Bruce Kulick. Even if you know all the information,here is a good place to turn to for additional good,interesting information ***and*** insight.EASTER EGG:Insert disc three,go to the "KISSOLOGY" logo on the screen,hit "enter",and you have an interview that was conducted with Mark St. John and Gene Simmons in 1984 regarding St. John's arrival in KISS. Unfortunate that this is the only real tribute that Mark St. John got,considering that "Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991" focuses a large part of its core on Eric Carr and his passing,alongside the fact that St. John passed with way less credit in KISS than Carr did. But--something is better than nothing. What you have here is worthwhile. Even though "Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991" could have done an overall better job at paying needed homage to ***both*** of the two fallen members of KISS,it still does its job.OVERALL:"Kiss:Kissology Volume II:1978-1991" succeeds in showing the latter years of KISS in a nutshell with richly executed selctions. Everything here is well organized and arranged--a good way to know and understand how KISS changed(personally and careerwise)once the infamous "Gene/Paul vs. Ace/Peter" show had taken its final toll on the band. A DVD that belongs right in the collection of KISS fans,and is well worth the time and the money.

reviewText: I'm kinda torn in my opinion of this collection.  On the one hand, what's here is absolute precious metal for the diehard KISS fan.  But I'm a tad disappointed and confused, as I thought perhaps that throughout the course of the planned three volumes of Kissology, it would manage to compile all of their promotional music videos through the years.  The inclusion of the "C'mon An' Love Me" and "Rock And Roll All Night" clips on Vol. 1 whetted my appetite that this collection, spanning the years 1978-1991, would include all promotional videos from that era as well - "I Was Made For Loving You", "Sure Know Something", "A World Without Heroes", "I Love It Loud", "Tears Are Falling", "Reason To Live", "Let's Put The 'X' In Sex", "Forever", and many more.But only two of them are included - the rarely-seen "Shandi" (never before available on any compilation), and "God Gave Rock And Roll To You II".  Both seem to be here to serve as statements for the events surrounding them.  "Shandi" was Peter Criss' last  appearance with the band (he had actually already been ousted from the group, they asked him to be in the video simply because they hadn't yet hired a new drummer) until the reunion in 1995, and "God Gave Rock And Roll To You II" was sadly the last appearance ever for Criss' replacement, Eric Carr, who passed away from cancer only a few months later.  The accompanying booklet and the audio commentary both mention how he had to wear a wig for this video due to the chemotherapy, and it's obvious that the camera is kept off of him as much as possible throughout the video.The band's so-cheesy-it's-good TV movie "Kiss Meets The Phantom Of The Park" is presented here in it's European theatrical version, with the slightly less dorky title of "Kiss in Attack Of The Phantom" (he's not really a phantom, but it sounds better than "Kiss in The Attack Of The Recently Down-Sized Animatronics Engineer Turned Evil Scientist").  It's nice to see the movie in widescreen with new edits and slightly upgraded special effects, but the inclusion of material from the four solo albums is distracting.  They seem to be randomly placed in the film during moments where a traditional mood-setting score would've worked much more effectively.The "Music From The Elder" three-song set from "Fridays" is something I've waited 25 years to see again, and it's exactly as I remember it - a top-notch performance.  Gene's singing on "A World Without Heroes" the best vocal job I've ever heard him do, blows away the studio version.  Conversely, Paul Stanley obviously can't hit the high notes he inflicted upon himself in "The Oath".But for me the real gem of this set is what is now officially the Best Concert Tour I Never Saw...the 1990 Hot In The Shade tour.  Reinvigorated with an expanded and completely revamped setlist that included long forgotten classics like "I Stole Your Love" and "God Of Thunder", as well as greatly renewed energy and the biggest stage show they'd done in years, KISS came out like they had something new to prove (good thing too, since the supporting album, "Hot In The Shade" was the WORST of their career).Volume 3 of course won't include too many music videos either, since the band has only released three studio albums since 1991.  That's fine, there will be no shortage of material from that era, but I do hope that at some point KISS releases a definitive compilation of all of their music videos.  Currently the ones that are available are spread out among outdated VHS titles lazily re-released on DVD, like "Exposed" and "X-Treme Close Up", surrounded by superfluous material and missing many videos from those respective eras.As for stuff that didn't make the cut for Volume 2 - it would've been nice to see the band's appearance on the long-forgotten Sunday morning children's show "Kids Are People Too" where they introduced Eric Carr, their appearance on a slightly-edgier Saturday morning kids' TV news magazine (I recall Ace Frehley saying "Playing guitar is kinda like making love," followed by his trademark cackle, and looking nervously at my Dad as we watched this over weekend breakfast), or Peter Criss' first public appearance without makeup on Tom Snyder's "Tomorrow" (a clip of the entire band's appearance on that show is included, with a bombed-out Ace Frehley completely dominating the proceedings).  But you could spend years trying to compile all of Kiss' various video artifacts over the years, and at some point it all starts to become overkill anyway.In short, you could nitpick this collection to death, but what's here is beautifully presented (if the audio and picture aren't always top notch - geez, that Australian concert is poor quality) and thoroughly documented by the band.  A must for any KISS fan.
summary: Wish It Had All The Videos...But What's Here Is Great

reviewText: I haven't had the time to sit down and read every single review and comment regarding KISSOLOGY 2, so if this has already been covered, I'm not aware of it. Odds are, it has; or something similar, anyway. At least, I would think so.I enjoy this DVD very much. It's great to see some of the shows and television appearances from the late `70s - early `80s that I was too busy growing up and earning a living to have seen! I don't mind the fact that several of the TV appearances were edited, really. Sure, it would have been nice to see them in their entirety, but KISS is far more about the music and the live shows than it is about the television interviews, anyway (although they certainly were about the hype and marketing, too).What I really don't care for, regarding this package, is the editing of the actual stage footage. I do understand that there may have been time considerations, and I do expect some, if not most, of the shows to have certain songs deleted, since they will have been played to death on previous shows (Rock and Roll All Night comes to mind) and on the first KISSOLOGY DVD. No, when I say `editing', what I mean is the fact that some songs are edited right in middle of them. For instance, during one show on the second disc, Eric Carr goes into a drum solo and when the band comes back onstage, they break out into God of Thunder. The problem with this is that it's an obvious continuation of the song, which was started before the drum solo, that they completely cut out. Gene has blood all over his face even though we never saw him spitting blood. This, of course, is a minor gripe, and I'm sure the intent was to give us a drum solo by Eric, which was great! There's just something about seeing this that makes me feel like I just missed something. Even though I have seen God of Thunder played on other concert sets, it still doesn't feel right. I don't watch all the concerts on this DVD set one right after another. I watch one of their shows then, a few days later, I pop the DVD in and settle down to watch a different show. I just feel a tiny bit cheated when I only see half of a song. I don't know, maybe it's just me.The third disc starts off with a concert in Brazil culled from the Creatures of the Night tour. All the banter by Paul (and anything else that may have occurred between songs) is completely dubbed out. After one song ends, you can see the film gets cut and goes immediately into the next song. Also, some of the songs themselves are cut short. On Black Diamond, Paul's wonderfully mellow guitar solo that leads into his shouting `Hit it!" is edited out, as the video picks up the song right after that. It rocks right up to the point where Vinnie is about to begin his solo, then suddenly we see a flash and the song picks up where the solo has ended. I would almost rather have had the song omitted completely from the play list than to have gears switched on me in mid-stream that way. It just doesn't feel right. Again, it's the feeling that I'm missing something (I was curious as to how Vinnie's lead solo differed from Ace's on the song, but never got the chance to find out).Lastly, I agree with others as to the curious omission of the band's body of work between Creatures of the Night and Crazy Nights. There is practically nothing, except for the occasional song during later concert footage, from the Lick it Up, Animalize and Asylum years, despite the fact that they had some great songs from those albums. Were they running that short of time on the DVD package? Were they completely `dissing' Mark St. John's contribution, for some reason? The concert footage jumps from the Vinnie Vincent years right to the Bruce Kulick years. What happened to Mark?There are a few other very minor points here and there that I could grouse about, but that would be unnecessary. If you are a KISS fan, you will appreciate and cherish KISSOLOGY 2. It is a creditable chronology of the band's work during a time of turmoil and transition and I give it 4 stars. The music and content would be easily worthy of 5 stars were it not for the over-editing and omissions, as described above. Still, all in all, great stuff!!Peace.
summary: You wanted the best, you got most of it....

Wow.).Shouldn't this disc also include the video's from this era? And where's the pro-shot concerts that exist from '83-84? I've seen them and they are far superior to what is here.
